Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: The regular backup is away, so most congregants expect him to step forward for the scheduled prayer.
Story: I glanced at my phone, my brother’s message lighting up the screen: “Don’t forget, you promised to come to dinner tonight. Everyone’s excited.” I smiled, remembering how we’d both agreed to make more time for each other, to not let our bond fade into the background of busy lives. But as I tucked the phone away, the mosque committee chair approached, his face earnest. “Imam, the backup is still out of town. The congregation is counting on you to lead Maghrib tonight.” I nodded, feeling the weight settle on my shoulders. My brother’s expectation was simple—show up, be present, share laughter and stories. The congregation’s was sacred—guide them in prayer, be the anchor of their faith. Both roles demanded my presence, both were rooted in respect and trust. My heart tugged in two directions, torn between the warmth of family and the solemn duty of faith. I sat quietly, wrestling with the knowledge that no matter what I chose, someone would be disappointed.
